title: New Console Generation
description: A new wave of hardware reset expectations for how big and cinematic games could be. Studios started investing in more detailed worlds and storytelling, while players grew used to longer, more polished experiences. It was a turning point that defined much of what 'mainstream gaming' would look like for the next decade.

title: Independent Expansion
description: Digital stores and accessible game engines opened the door for smaller teams to create and publish their own work. Indie projects started shaping the conversation around creativity and experimentation. The industry began to feel less centralized, with new voices and ideas gaining traction outside traditional studio systems.

title: Streaming and Social Discovery
description: Streaming platforms changed how people found and talked about games. Watching others play became part of the experience, helping certain titles explode in popularity overnight. Developers began thinking about community and shareability as much as core gameplay.

title: The Rise of Competitive Play
description: Online multiplayer became a major driver of engagement as competition and live updates kept players coming back. Games were increasingly built as ongoing communities rather than one-time releases, reflecting a shift toward long-term connection over completion.

title: Interactive Escapism
description: Global disruptions brought people indoors and online, turning games into social spaces and coping tools. Cozy and creative experiences grew in popularity as players looked for comfort and connection. It was a reminder that games can be more than entertainment. They can be a form of community and self-expression.
